title: How many confirmed cases of COVID-19 will have been reported by the World Health Organization (WHO) for the United Kingdom as of 1 June 2020?
possible_answers: More than 65,000 but less than 105,000 cases
preds: Consideration of past few days' figures. Unfortunately <145K seems very unlikely.

This assessment is on the basis of considering a logistic fit and the variation in growth rates, over shorter and longer terms. Edit: I've now looked at other forecasters' assessments. 100% for >145K breaks Cromwell's rule :-) And the WHO figures are slightly smaller than the Worldometer figures. The last few days' increases have been higher than my logistic curve best fit, but comparing with the fit over a longer term suggests this won't continue. On the other hand, the divergence could be a testing artefact, in which case it may continue and perhaps I'm on the low side for >145K. I seem to be differing from the "crowd" anyway. I expect to revise a few times over the next few days.
sorry read deaths instead of cases...

It's super obvious to everyone, but for the sake of the methodology:  As of 16 April 2020 the UK numbers were as follows: 
*Total confirmed cases: 109,754
* New cases: 4,617 
* Average testing rate for the last seven days: 12,026.71/day  Even if the rates will stay the same*, UK will go over 145,000 on 28 April 2020. I would assign this answer more than 90% probability even if it was closing on 1 May 2020.    Footnotes and assumptions:
*My assumption is that the numbers of both tests and daily confirmed cases will rise significantly:  The testing rate will go up as the government is under pressure to ramp up the testing; and the percentage of infected population in the UK is probably higher than 5.4% which is the high end of the Imperial College's conservative estimate of '% of total population infected' from 28 March 2020)   Sources:  https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/full-list-covid-19-tests-per-day?country=GBR https://gisanddata.maps.arcgis.com/apps/opsdashboard/index.html#/bda7594740fd40299423467b48e9ecf6 https://www.imperial.ac.uk/media/imperial-college/medicine/mrc-gida/2020-03-30-COVID19-Report-13.pdf

The challenge is to predict the confirmed number of infections.  So the availability, and reliability, of testing plays a part.  I'm buying a little insurance, decreasing the prediction for the worst case outcome (>145,000) from 100% to 93%.

There are currently 55k cases in the UK as of today (April 8th). We can rule out <25k. The number of cases has been increasing at about 4.5k cases per day. It seems safe to also rule out 25k-65k. To get under 105k, the average number of new cases over the next 50 days would have to be less than 1000. We have yet to see containment even close to that effective, so we can rule that one out too. The question is now: what is the probability that the number of cases passes 145k? That comes out to an average growth rate of about 1.7k. That would also take pretty good containment, but I don't think it is completely out of the question. I think 14:1 odds is reasonable.
Looking at @Gjlewis answer and considering the impact of social distancing I substantially adjusted my estimates. I will continue assess the impact of social distancing.
Number of daily new cases ist going down inspite of increased testing, and 145K is far away. https://www.worldometers.info/coronavirus/country/uk/

Tricky. UK cases are currently ~ 55k, with an increase of ~ 4k per day. If this continues, you comfortably exceed 145. But many (many) adjustments: 1. Cumulative case curves are typically sigmoid, and the now linear-ish trend would suggest we're around the inflexion point. If so, roughly doubling from nowish gives you a number 80-120kish. 2. However, it is probably only sigmoid given containment strategy, so there's some chance of this being inadvertently or deliberately relaxed, which could further push up the numbers.  3. Testing. I take this to be the principal uncertainty - I guess there have already been 145k infections in the UK (and certainly will have been by Jun 1) - the question is how many end up being recognised and reported. Briefly: * We saw large 'steps' in reported cases when China switched for a time to clinical case definitions. However, cumulative curves seen elsewhere do not show (to my knowledge) large surges of cases attributable to testing. I suspect partly because these surges happen after containment has already kicked in, and mild/asymptomatic cases in the community tend not to be sought (and prioritized below HCWs, patients, etc.) * Current tests assess (roughly) current infection, and not past ones. Also reagents are short worldwide, so it remains unclear whether the UK will hit 100k tests a day soon. * Antibody tests may be implemented soonish, and their widespread deployment could reveal thousands of seroconversions. Yet seroconversion does not demonstrate a current infection, and thus it is unclear to me whether this would 'count' as a case for reporting purposes. There's also a question of if (e.g.) there's a rollout of 'home test kits' whether there would be attempts to gather the 'positives' and report them.   Trying to weigh this up, I'm much more cautious than the crowd. Perhaps they know something I don't.
Responding to today's low case-count. See prior estimate for a more elaborate analysis.
Updating my forecast due to recent development in growth rates

We can conservatively forecast the near term with more accuracy than the full period. I see a week at 4K+ (by April 12) and another week at 3K+ (April 19) which adds a combined 49 to the current (approx. 48) for a total of 97K cases.  At that point we are 48K short of 145 cases, and there area 41 days remaining. The average for the remaining 41 days would have to be below 1,170 cases.   The UK data seems a bit sketchier than some countries making the forecast a bit riskier, as does the relatively short period since the jump in case counts: We didn't hit 3000 until 6 days ago. What argues for a high estimate is the recent history of spain, italy, and france. They will all be over 145K by the deadline, but the current UK count is significantly lower in spite of its being as large or larger than those countries and not responding quickly or well. The UK's testing has lagged even the US in tests per million people. On the other hand, UK is promising a big increase in testing which should push numbers up as it rolls out, even if it decreases them later.  Also, the remaining period is sufficiently long that we can't rule out entirely some clinical or epidemiological innovation that impacts the case count positively.  The most likely course is continued growth in the UK daily case numbers as testing increases. If the total is much below 76,000 on 12th or 97,000 on the 19th we should reduce the probability for over 145. If it's much over, we should increase it.

Viral experts expect COVID-19 to peek in around 12-16 weeks.  Because COVID-19 is a virus, it will follow the epidemiological growth pattern, doubling approximately every 6 days. Using 13 weeks or  91 days to the expected peek, and if COVID-19 cases double every 6 days, you can expect ~15 doublings (91/6) before the peek is reached. Working backwards, on 1st March 2020 (June 1st 2020 - 13 weeks) the number of COVID-19 cases in the UK was 35. 15 doublings, starting at 35 gives 573,440 cases.  145,000 is only ~25% of this number and is conservative since the start value is 35. Using a start value of 100 brings the number to 1.6 million after 15 doublings. Therefore my estimate for the UK to have at least 145,000 by June the 1st seems a reasonable guess.   (Even if prevention measures like social distancing work as expected)

In the past week (March 22-29), the growth rate of cases was 243% (5,683 to 19,522). If that rate were to keep up, on June 1st (which is in nine weeks' time), the number of cases would be over a billion. This is obviously impossible given that the UK's population is only about 65 million. More realistically, if I were to assume UK cases grow by 3,000-4,000 per day (last couple days are 2.5-3k, roughly), I would anticipate that the UK will hit the upper bound of 145,000 cases sometime between April 30th-May 9th. The UK government has been slow to enact social distancing measures, relative to other countries (https://www.nationalreview.com/2020/03/coronavirus-outbreak-united-kingdom-response-outlier/, https://www.city-journal.org/britain-shifting-covid-19-strategies) - so, barring drastic action and a lot of luck (i.e., the disease behaving differently than it has elsewhere),  I would not anticipate a meaningful slowdown of growth.

UK as of WHO webpage currently has 11662 cases. Arguments for a high number:
- From the number of cases as well as deaths it looks like the UK is lagging Italy by around 2 weeks. Similary, the lock-down of the UK was implented at a similar stage of the exponential curve as Italy. Therefore, extrapolating using the Italian data we get to above 80k cases over the next 2 weeks for the UK (using Johns Hopkins data). The WHO data is consistently a bit lower than Johns Hopkins but this should rule out the first two answer possibilities very firmly. Given that even with a lock-down the growth rate takes time to stabilize (Italy still has 6k new cases per day recently) staying below 105k cases also seems very unlikely.
- Further following the Italian data thought experiment if we assume that the current (27 March) growth rate of new cases drops by 0.5% per day until it reaches 1% and then with 0.1% per day until it hits zero on 19 April Italy will still have reached 147k cases by then; UK being two weeks behind would get to that number end of April/beginning of May then
- Even if the lock-down is successful, this will be followed by a period when the lock-down is lifted (even if slowly) where there will be new infections, which in upside scenario should be held in check via tests and contact tracing, however still leading to continuous low number of new infections (in South Korea ~100 per day)
- Furthermore, the UK government is working on introducing antibody tests which would reveal who was infected without having been testet. Assuming this is implemented before June (likely if the tests work) then the cases should spike substantially (assuming they will count towards the WHO cases which in turn is uncertain)
- Also any increase in testing capacities would likely lead to even higher numbers Arguments for lower number:
- testing in UK is not done very thoroughly. Government instruction to people is that everyone who has symptoms (fever, cough) should self isolate for 7 days and not contact the authorities unless the situation worsens significantly. Therefore the dark figure is significantly higher and reported cases could stay below 145k
- further reduction of tests could lead to even higher difference between actual number 
- the main risk of this question is the difference between actual cases (which likely are above 145k already in UK incl all untested cases) vs what is reported by the WHO

The UK's confirmation rate (confirmed cases/tests) is increasing rapidly (3/26 11% vs 3/19 5% and 3/12 2%), suggesting widespread infection that testing is lagging behind (testing is growing 7-8%/d while confirmed cases are growing close to 20%/day). Charts can be seen at https://docs.google.com/document/d/1n3Rh0d1ewmay_MVS3fa6uOHbSMpF9tHD39_WXXb6vVI/edit?usp=sharing The most reliable (though still imperfect) covid-19 statistic currently available is deaths and the UK's current daily deaths are 50-60, which suggest 500k-5m are currently infected based on my model (https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1GnMIErovcmjxt0dYbAjmegViJNjy5G745j_QWZQgIGw/edit?usp=sharing) It's only a matter of time before testing catches up with reality. PS - UK COVID-19 testing is "2nd tier" with 1553 total tests per million residents and close to 100/MM/day. Italy's figures are 3-4x that, US total tests similar but daily testing rate is ~200/MM/day. "Top tier" be small nations like Bahrain that has tested 18k/MM and averages close to 1000/MM/day. (All numbers as of 3/26)

Stats: 26th March 2020 11,658 cases, 104,866 tested. First case 28th Feb. 67 days until 1st June 2020. UK in lockdown. UK population ~ 66 million. Similar areas for comparison, Italy and Spain - 80,000 cases, 56,000 cases respectively.  Logarithmic scale for the UK with trend line 
https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:CoViD-19_GB.svg In less than a month nearly 10,000 cases - at a low rate of spread and low levels of testing. Current new cases around 1500 a day, likely to increase. Currently the UK is only testing those in serious condition or already in hospital (and other key individuals). Large scale testing of essential workers is likely to be introduced.  Almost certain that there will be more than 145,000 cases in the UK. Unknown is whether testing can confirm these numbers. Introduction of “at home” antibody testing raises queries if these would “count” towards WHO figures.  Highly likely that NHS staff will be tested - government ordered 3.5 million tests. Likely these will count towards official figures.  Around 1 million NHS staff, 500,000 of which are doctors and nurses. Unknown what percentage of these are frontline and likely to be or have already been infected. Likely that their families will also be tested (assume 2-3 people per household).  Other key industries include transport, government, food manufacturing, education, waste disposal etc. Likely these will be tested within the timeframe.  Largest query concerns the effectiveness of social distancing. Modelling by Imperial College suggested that no social distancing would result in almost complete infection of the UK and 100,000s of deaths.  My forecast is based on these factors. If the essential staff testing does not count (for whatever reason) to WHO figures, my initial forecast is incorrect and needs to be reduced.
Considering increased testing availability/ home testing kits, the peak of positive cases, and control wrt quarantine.
No reason to expect better than Italy or Spain
